s.text: Choosing the GoCharts module opens a new window with a variety options.
DAVID's functionality is demonstrated using the Affymetrix GeneChip data of Cicala et al . [ 10 ] .
Also included are options to annotate gene lists with all GO terms available or only the most specific terms, which are referred to as terminal nodes.

The server time required for execution of this module correlates linearly with the size of the gene list and takes less than 45 seconds for lists of up to 1,000 genes (Figure 2, numbers in parentheses represent r 2values).
Classification data is displayed as a bar chart, where the length of the bar represents the number of gene identifiers in each category.
With each increasing level coverage decreases while specificity increases so that level 5 provides the least amount of coverage with the highest term specificity.
Choosing molecular function, level 3 produces a new histogram that quickly reveals that nearly half (16/35) of the stress-response genes possess cytokine activity (Figure 4c).
After choosing a classification type, levels that determine list coverage and specificity are chosen by selecting the appropriate radio button.
Choosing molecular function, level 3 produces a new histogram that quickly reveals that nearly half (16/35) of the stress-response genes possess cytokine activity (Figure 4c).
Any combination of classification and coverage level can be specified.
Any combination of annotation data can be chosen from 10 options by selecting the appropriate checkboxes (Table 2).

In particular, high-density biochips including complementary deoxyribonucleic acid (cDNA) microarrays, oligonucleotide microarrays, and rapidly evolving proteomics platforms represent modern tools able to interrogate biology on a genome-wide scale and generate tens of thousands of data points simultaneously [ 1 ] . While researchers are beginning to appreciate the statistical rigors required for the analysis of genome-scale datasets, a rate-limiting step in knowledge growth occurs at the transition from statistical significance to biological discovery.
